verses.text: When the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon's fame, she came to Jerusalem to test Solomon with hard questions. She arrived with a very large entourage, with camels carrying spices, an abundance of gold, and precious stones. When she came to Solomon, she spoke with him about all that was on her heart.
verses.comment: Solomon's international reputation for wisdom draws foreign rulers, foreshadowing the spread of divine wisdom to the nations. The Queen of Sheba's visit is a vivid testament to God's faithfulness as wisdom brings rulers from afar (cf. Matthew 12:42, where Jesus refers to this event).

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions; nothing was too difficult for Solomon to explain to her.
verses.comment: Solomon’s divine gift of wisdom is highlighted. He is an image of the perfect wisdom fulfilled in Christ, who has the answers to all hearts’ questions (cf. Col. 2:3).

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba saw Solomon's wisdom, the palace he had built,
verses.comment: The Queen’s amazement arises not just from Solomon’s words, but the visible order of his kingdom, representative of the harmony God desires in his people.

verses.text: the food at his table, the seating of his officials, the attendance of his servants and their attire, his cupbearers and their clothing, and the burnt offerings which he offered at the house of the LORD, she was overwhelmed.
verses.comment: The daily order, liturgical worship, and ceremonial offerings at the temple deeply impress her. The emphasis on offerings to the LORD foreshadows the importance of worship through sacred liturgy for the people of God.

verses.text: She said to the king, 'The report I heard in my own land about your words and your wisdom was true.
verses.comment: Fulfillment of wisdom’s reputation. A testimony that wisdom, when lived out, draws seekers from even the most distant lands (cf. Isaiah 2:3).

verses.text: 'But I did not believe their words until I came and saw with my own eyes. In fact, not even half of your great wisdom was told to me; you surpass what I had heard.
verses.comment: True wisdom cannot fully be described but must be experienced—prefiguring how the fullness of divine truth is encountered not merely in words, but in person and reality.

verses.text: 'How happy your men must be! How blessed your servants, who continually stand before you and hear your wisdom.
verses.comment: Joy comes from drawing near to wisdom and abiding in the king's presence. This mirrors the joy of being in God’s presence in worship.

verses.text: 'Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delighted in you, setting you on his throne as king for the LORD your God. Because your God loved Israel, to establish them forever, he has made you king over them to maintain justice and righteousness.'
verses.comment: The Queen acknowledges that Solomon’s kingship and Israel’s permanence are based in God's faithful love. The throne is God’s, stewarded by Solomon, a biblical model for authority deriving from God Himself—a principle crucial for understanding later New Testament theology (cf. Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: Then she gave the king one hundred and twenty talents of gold, a great quantity of spices, and precious stones. There was never before such abundance of spices as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
verses.comment: The queen’s offerings are a symbol of the nations bringing their treasures to God’s appointed ruler—an image fulfilled ultimately in the Magi’s gifts to Christ (see Matthew 2:11).

verses.text: Moreover, the servants of Huram and the servants of Solomon, who brought gold from Ophir, also brought algum wood and precious stones.
verses.comment: International partnerships contributed to the beauty of the temple and the king’s house. The church’s beauty is enhanced by the diversity of gifts brought by all people.

verses.text: The king made steps from the algum wood for the house of the LORD and for the king's house, and lyres and harps for the singers; there had never been seen anything like them before in the land of Judah.
verses.comment: The gifts are used for liturgical worship and enhancing sacred space, showing that artistic beauty glorifies God and serves worship. Instrumental music figures in sacred celebrations.

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba all she desired, whatever she asked for, more than she had brought to the king. Then she returned to her own country with her servants.
verses.comment: Solomon’s generosity exceeds that of the Queen, a foreshadow of how Christ gives grace abundantly to all who seek Him (cf. John 1:16).

verses.text: The weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred and sixty-six talents of gold,
verses.comment: The number 666 here records royal income; the symbolism of this number appears later in Revelation in a negative sense, but here simply marks Solomon’s wealth at its height.

verses.text: apart from what traders and merchants brought. All the kings of Arabia and the governors of the land also brought gold and silver to Solomon.
verses.comment: The nations stream to Jerusalem with their gifts, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies that the Gentiles would come to Zion (see Isaiah 60:3-6).

verses.text: King Solomon made two hundred large shields of hammered gold; six hundred shekels of hammered gold went into each shield.
verses.comment: Great golden shields are both symbols of protection and regal splendor, fitting for the king chosen by God to shepherd his people.

verses.text: He made three hundred small shields of hammered gold; three hundred shekels of gold went into each shield. The king put them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.comment: The House of the Forest of Lebanon was a royal complex. The use of gold underscores the prosperity of Solomon’s reign—an image of the king’s role as guardian and provider.

verses.text: The king also made a great throne of ivory, and overlaid it with pure gold.
verses.comment: The throne’s opulence points to the unique dignity of Solomon’s kingship—ultimately fulfilled in Christ, the true King enthroned in heavenly glory (cf. Revelation 3:21).

verses.text: The throne had six steps, and a footstool of gold was attached to it. On each side of the seat were armrests, and two lions stood beside the armrests.
verses.comment: The lions symbolize royal strength and majesty. The footstool echoes God’s throne in the temple (cf. Psalm 99:5), reinforcing the idea of royal authority under divine sovereignty.

verses.text: Twelve lions stood on the six steps, one on each end of the six steps. Nothing like it was made for any kingdom.
verses.comment: The twelve lions probably represent the twelve tribes of Israel—hinting at the unity and completeness envisioned under one king. Such unity foreshadows New Testament images of the one people of God.

verses.text: All King Solomon's drinking vessels were of gold, and all the vessels of the House of the Forest of Lebanon were of pure gold; silver was not considered anything in Solomon's days.
verses.comment: Lavish royal feasts evoke the theme of the messianic banquet—in Christ, the abundance of the kingdom is spiritual as much as material (cf. Revelation 19:9).

verses.text: The king's ships went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram; every three years they returned, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
verses.comment: Solomon’s domain touches the farthest reaches of the known world, gathering the riches of creation—an anticipation of all creation being renewed in Christ (Romans 8:19-21).

verses.text: So King Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in riches and in wisdom.
verses.comment: Solomon is a type—a foreshadowing—of Christ the Wisdom of God, whose glory far surpasses all earthly kings and rulers.

verses.text: All the kings of the earth sought the presence of Solomon to hear his wisdom, which God had put in his heart.
verses.comment: True wisdom, as a divine gift, draws all the nations. The Gentiles’ coming to Solomon prefigures the nations seeking Christ and the worship of the one God.

verses.text: Each one brought his present—articles of silver and gold, garments, weapons, spices, horses, and mules—a set amount year after year.
verses.comment: Regular gifts to Solomon symbolize worship and devotion, reflecting the biblical principle that the nations will bring their gifts to Jerusalem (cf. Isaiah 60:5-7).

verses.text: Solomon had four thousand stalls for horses and chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen, whom he stationed in chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Solomon’s military might and infrastructure display the full flowering of the kingdom. Care is taken to note the order and discipline in the king’s service.

verses.text: He ruled over all the kings from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines and as far as the border of Egypt.
verses.comment: Solomon’s kingdom fulfills God’s ancient promise to Abraham. The universal kingdom prefigures Christ’s reign over all nations (cf. Luke 1:33).

verses.text: The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and cedars as plentiful as sycamore trees in the lowland.
verses.comment: This image of abundance and blessing is a foretaste of the fullness and prosperity of the messianic age found in Christ.

verses.text: Solomon's horses were imported from Egypt and from all the lands.
verses.comment: Royal trade routes reach from Egypt throughout the known world—illustrating the king’s impressive reach and worldliness.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Solomon, from the beginning to the end, are they not written in the records of Nathan the prophet, in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam son of Nebat?
verses.comment: The Chronicler refers to multiple sources—prophetic and historical—emphasizing the importance of both Scripture and tradition in preserving God’s works.

verses.text: Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel forty years.
verses.comment: The forty-year reign echoes the biblical pattern for periods of testing and fulfillment—seen elsewhere with Moses and David.

verses.text: Then Solomon rested with his fathers and was buried in the city of David his father. And Rehoboam his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: The orderly succession of kingship, and burial among the fathers, anticipates the ongoing continuity of God’s promises through a sacred lineage, ultimately fulfilled in Christ (cf. Matthew 1:6-7).
